text: Trigger Mechanism for
label: HH1

text: Anticipatory Action in the Central American Dry Corridor (CADC)
label: HH2

text: Technical Note
label: BODY

text: Version 3 (01 March 2024)
label: BODY

text: Anticipatory action is planned to preemptively intervene against drought-related impacts in the
label: BODY

text: Central American Dry Corridor (CADC) that runs through Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, and
label: BODY

text: El Salvador. A framework was developed collaboratively by the regional and national partners
label: BODY

text: and the Centre for Humanitarian Data (CHD). It includes pre-agreed financing, pre-selected
label: BODY

text: interventions, and a trigger for automated activation. This note describes the technical aspects
label: BODY

text: of the trigger mechanism.
label: BODY

text: Trigger Development
label: BODY

text: The CHD led the development of the technical development of the trigger mechanism with
label: BODY

text: inputs from regional and local partners . The requirements for the mechanism were identified
label: BODY

text: through conversations with the regional and national partners. Options for the mechanism were
label: BODY

text: defined, validated against historical data, discussed with stakeholders, and tuned over several
label: BODY

text: iterations. The version of the mechanism discussed in this note has been approved by the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian country team and is currently being monitored for potential activations in 2024.
label: BODY

text: Trigger Overview
label: BODY

text: The Anticipatory Action (AA) project focuses on the 4 primary countries through which the
label: BODY

text: CADC spans: Nicaragua, El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras. The triggering mechanism is
label: BODY

text: based on the seasonal rainfall forecast with threshold set for individual countries based on
label: BODY

text: historical seasonal rainfall forecasts and estimated return periods. Based on the requirements
label: BODY

text: from operational partners the following analytical decisions had to be made:
label: BODY

text: Table 1. Key trigger design decisions
label: BODY

text: Decision Type
label: BODY

text: Decision made
label: BODY

text: Event Type
label: BODY

text: MJJA & SON seasonal rainfall deficit
label: BODY

text: Geographic level of analysis
label: BODY

text: Country level
label: BODY

text: Forecast lead time
label: BODY

text: Up to 4 months
label: BODY

text: Activation thresholds
label: BODY

text: 1 in 4 year rainfall deficit
label: BODY

text: Forecast to use
label: BODY

text: ECMWF SEAS 51/ National Forecast
label: BODY

text: (INSIVUMEH for Guatemala only)
label: BODY

text: The rationale and description of each of these decisions is provided in the next section with
label: BODY

text: more additional details provided in the Appendix section.
label: BODY

text: Rationale
label: BODY

text: Event Type
label: BODY

text: The trigger is designed to monitor seasonal drought as measured by forecasted cumulative
label: BODY

text: seasonal rainfall deficit. Country and regional partners identified the two key seasons for
label: BODY

text: monitoring as the Primera (May - August) and Postrera (September - November) seasons. If
label: BODY

text: critical rainfall deficits/drought conditions are forecasted in either window, the AA framework is
label: BODY

text: to be activated.
label: BODY

text: Geographic level of analysis
label: BODY

text: The analysis and monitoring occurs at the country level. All countries are monitored
label: BODY

text: simultaneously with the same framework and decision logic, but can be activated independently
label: BODY

text: and at different times. To allow operational flexibility in targeting, the analysis was conducted
label: BODY

text: over the entirety of each country to ensure that no area of possible intervention/activity was
label: BODY

text: excluded.
label: BODY

text: Forecast used
label: BODY

text: The use of ECMWF, IRI, and national forecast data were assessed for all four countries during
label: BODY

text: the design process.
label: BODY

text: Where possible, the use of national forecast data was prioritized.
label: BODY

text: Guatemala was the only country for which in-county partners could secure national forecast
label: BODY

text: data. Therefore, the agreed upon forecast data sources for the trigger are:
label: BODY

text: Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador - ECMWF Seasonal Forecast
label: BODY

text: Page 2 of 10
label: BODY

text: Guatemala - Official national forecast provided the Instituto nacional
label: BODY

text: de Sismología,
label: BODY

text: Vulcanologia, Meteorologia e Hidrología (INSIVUMEH) for all months except May where
label: BODY

text: the national forecast does not provide a prediction for publication month as required by
label: BODY

text: the implementing partners (Figure 1). For this month ECMWF Seasonal will be used.
label: BODY

text: For a more in depth discussion of the forecast data source please see the appendix below.
label: BODY

text: Forecast Lead Time
label: BODY

text: The forecast lead times used for the framework monitoring
label: BODY

text: were decided based on the
label: BODY

text: operational requirements of implementing partners and constraints of forecast data products.
label: BODY

text: Each monthly global ECMWF forecast publication provides 7 monthly lead times including the
label: BODY

text: forecast for the month of forecast publication whereas INSIVUMEH forecast provides 6 monthly
label: BODY

text: lead times with the first month being the month after publication of the forecast. During the
label: BODY

text: design process the CHD provided analysis and specific thresholds for each possible lead time
label: BODY

text: and provided the recommendation to adopt the shortest lead time possible that still would
label: BODY

text: provide the partners with sufficient time to implement activities.
label: BODY

text: After reviewing all activities, stakeholders/partners agreed to the following lead times and
label: BODY

text: monitoring periods:
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Thresholds
label: BODY

text: Thresholds were based on a 1 in 4 year return period (RP) event and calculated independently
label: BODY

text: for each country. For each year of historical seasonal forecast
label: BODY

text: data (1981-2022) the total
label: BODY

text: seasonal rainfall (for each season) was calculated and averaged to each of the countries
label: BODY

text: boundaries for each lead time. This historical record was then used to calculate the threshold
label: BODY

text: that corresponded to 25 % activation rate (or 1 in 4 year RP). This process was run on both
label: BODY

text: ECMWF seasonal and national forecast (for Guatemala) data separately.
label: BODY

text: Thresholds were
label: BODY

text: calculated per country, activation window, lead time, and forecast data source to compensate
label: BODY

text: for any bias in forecast values across lead times (see Appendix for additional details).
label: BODY

text: Monitoring
label: BODY

text: The CHD is responsible for monitoring the seasonal forecast and updating the activation status
label: BODY

text: on a monthly basis with an automated email alert to relevant stakeholders. As the ECMWF
label: BODY

text: Seasonal forecast is published on the 5th of each month, the trigger notification for Nicaragua,
label: BODY

text: Honduras, and El Salvador are distributed on the 5th of each month. INSIVUMEH provided a date
label: BODY

text: range for the Guatemala national forecast publication as the 5th-10th each month. Therefore,
label: BODY

text: the Guatemala trigger status update is made upon receival of this forecast. No cutoff date has
label: BODY

text: been established for using the national forecast in Guatemala, but is at the discretion of CERF
label: BODY

text: and partners based on operational requirements. The monitoring is automated through a GitHub
label: BODY

text: action available in this GitHub repository.
label: BODY

text: Page 4 of 10
label: BODY

text: Appendix
label: BODY

text: Forecast (Lead Time & Data Source)
label: BODY

text: Data sources & Accessibility: to monitor seasonal drought, seasonal forecasts were required.
label: BODY

text: The trigger was designed with flexibility to incorporate national forecast data sources
label: BODY

text: where/when available and global data sets when no national forecasts could be obtained. Thus
label: BODY

text: far Guatemala’s national forecast provided by INSIVUMEH was the only national forecast data
label: BODY

text: set that could be obtained by in-country partners.
label: BODY

text: For Nicaragua, Guatemala, and El Salvador where no national forecast data could be secured,
label: BODY

text: ECMWF and IRI global forecasts were evaluated. ECMWF was eventually chosen over IRI for the
label: BODY

text: following reasons:
label: BODY

text: ECMWF provides hindcast/forecast data from 1981 to present compared to IRI which is
label: BODY

text: only available from 2017 onwards. The longer historical record of ECMWF allows the
label: BODY

text: calculation of
label: BODY

text: activation rates at different thresholds with a much higher degree of
label: BODY

text: confidence.
label: BODY

text: ECMWF provides monthly total precipitation which allows flexible temporal aggregation
label: BODY

text: whereas IRI only provides trimester (3-month) probabilities
label: BODY

text: ECMWF is released earlier in the month (5th compared to 16th)
label: BODY

text: ECMWF units are easily converted to total precipitation which is easier for stakeholders
label: BODY

text: to understand than tercile probabilities
label: BODY

text: ECMWF seasonal forecast data obtained from the MARS catalog can be provided at 0.4
label: BODY

text: degrees resolution which is a higher resolution than IRI data which can only be obtained
label: BODY

text: at 1 degree resolution.
label: BODY

text: The ECMWF Seasonal forecast is made public through the Copernicus Data Store (CDS) on the
label: BODY

text: 5th of every month. This publicly available data has a resolution of 1 degree and contains 6
label: BODY

text: months of lead time (including publication month). The full ECMWF SEAS5 historical forecast
label: BODY

text: data set which includes 7 months of lead time and has a resolution of 0.4 degrees is available to
label: BODY

text: World Meteorological Organization (WMO) members through the ECMWF MARS catalog. For
label: BODY

text: up-to-date ECMWF data with the full 7 months of lead time at 0.4 degrees resolution the CHD
label: BODY

text: receives the seasonal forecast data directly from ECMWF.
label: BODY

text: Operational requirements:
label: BODY

text: AA partners compiled a list of required start times by activity and agency (Figure 2). After
label: BODY

text: receiving the required lead times by agencies and conducting a deep dive session it was
label: BODY

text: decided to remove the February forecast publication from the Primera monitoring window and
label: BODY

text: September from the Postrera monitoring window. This was done based on the activity timeline
label: BODY

text: (Figure 2) and to standardize the monitoring period and probability of activation across
label: BODY

text: countries and while reducing uncertainty in trigger mechanism.
label: BODY

text: Page 5 of 10
label: BODY

text: Figure 2. Timeline of activities and required activation months
label: BODY

text: Thresholds/Trigger
label: BODY

text: As no drought impact data was available in the regions, the thresholds were set primarily based
label: BODY

text: on historical activation rates/return period level calculations. The threshold was finally set to
label: BODY

text: activate only if the seasonal rainfall was forecasted to be at least a 1 in 4 year return period level
label: BODY

text: deficit at any lead time. The calculated thresholds based on the 4 year return period levels are
label: BODY

text: presented below in tables 3 and 4 for the Primera and Postrera season, respectively.
label: BODY

text: Page 6 of 10
label: BODY

text: Table 3. Primera Thresholds
label: BODY

text: Table 4. Postrera Thresholds
label: BODY

text: Page 7 of 10
label: BODY

text: The analytical method for historical analysis/thresholding can be conceptualized as two steps:
label: BODY

text: 1. Data aggregation, 2. Return period/activation rate calculation & bias correction.
label: BODY

text: Aggregation
label: BODY

text: Thresholds were designed using ECMWF SEAS5 seasonal precipitation forecast from the public
label: BODY

text: Copernicus Data Store & MARS catalog as well as the national seasonal precipitation forecast
label: BODY

text: for Guatemala provided by INSIVUMEH . All available historical forecast data from 1981-2022
label: BODY

text: was downloaded and processed for historical analyses. The data was downloaded as monthly
label: BODY

text: precipitation rate estimates over the area of interest, for each month the mean of the 51
label: BODY

text: ensemble members was calculated at the pixel level to obtain 1 raster per month.
label: BODY

text: The average monthly precipitation was then extracted for every month and lead time for each
label: BODY

text: country by an area-weighted mean statistic. The zonal mean statistic was chosen as the
label: BODY

text: aggregation method for simplification purposes.
label: BODY

text: The monthly zonal statistics were then
label: BODY

text: aggregated temporally to the seasonal windows (MJJA & SON) for each lead time combination
label: BODY

text: available.
label: BODY

text: Threshold Setting & Bias Correction
label: BODY

text: From the yearly historical data, the 25th percentile (1 in 4 year RP level) was calculated for each
label: BODY

text: country,
label: BODY

text: window, and lead time. The percentile calculation was performed at each lead time
label: BODY

text: separately as different lead times can be biased in a number of ways. For example, across all
label: BODY

text: four countries of interest, we see that the ECMWF seasonal forecast systematically predicts
label: BODY

text: lower rainfall quantities at longer lead times during the Primera season (Figure 3).
label: BODY

text: calculating the percentiles for each lead time separately we ensure equal probability across all
label: BODY

text: relevant forecast publication months.
label: BODY

text: Page 8 of 10
label: BODY

text: Figure 3. Forecasted rainfall bias by country and lead time during the primera season (ECMWF Seasonal).
label: BODY

text: It must be noted that by setting a threshold at the 4 year return period level and monitoring each
label: BODY

text: publication month/lead time independently, the joint probability of activation across any
label: BODY

text: forecast publication months rises substantially. Additionally, when considering, the probability of
label: BODY

text: activation across either season (Primera/Postrera)
label: BODY

text: this joint probability of activation rises
label: BODY

text: further. These joint activation rates were discussed in the CADC AA Deep dive session led by
label: BODY

text: CERF & the CHD and were considered in the final decision to choose a 1 in 4 year RP level for
label: BODY

text: monitoring at each forecast publication date. Table 5 presents the joint activation rate across all
label: BODY

text: lead times for each season as well as combined activation rates across seasons based on the
label: BODY

text: thresholds and activation points presented in tables 3 & 4.
label: BODY

text: Table 5. Joint Return Periods/Activation Rates
label: BODY

text: Page 9 of 10
label: BODY

text: Observation Indicators Consideration/Exclusion
label: BODY

text: Observational crop/vegetation monitoring with indicators such as Vegetative Health Index (VHI)
label: BODY

text: & Agricultural Stress Index System (ASIS) were considered, but left out of the framework as data
label: BODY

text: obtained during the identified critical seasons (as opposed to before) can’t preemptively inform
label: BODY

text: or support the bulk of AA activities focused on agricultural provided by operational partners
label: BODY

text: which must be implemented before the growing period commences.
label: BODY

text: The use of observational vegetative health indicators was initially proposed by the partners in
label: BODY

text: early iterations of the framework.
label: BODY

text: After initial investigation of VHI and ASIS by the CHD
label: BODY

text: according to various framework revisions suggested by FAO, FAO recommended removing ASIS
label: BODY

text: from consideration as it is meant to be monitored during certain stages of the growing season
label: BODY

text: which do not align with lead time/operational requirements of the agencies. The use of VHI to
label: BODY

text: capture pre-existing vulnerabilities and thereby condition triggers was suggested, but a coherent
label: BODY

text: strategy that could align with operational requirements of agencies was not found or adopted.
label: BODY

text: Areas for Improvement in future iterations
label: BODY

text: The following two potential areas of improvement were identified and may be considered in
label: BODY

text: future iterations of the framework:
label: BODY

text: Integration of additional national forecast data sources.
label: BODY

text: Observational indicators such as VHI could be further explored with key inputs from
label: BODY

text: partners.
label: BODY

text: Contact the OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data via Zachary Arno, Data Scientist at
label: BODY

text: zachary.arno@un.org with any questions or feedback.
